feed.title: Lewis & Clark Digital Collections
feed.subtitle: A collection of digital content from the collections of the Lewis & Clark College Special Collection and Archives.

author.name: Special Collections, Watzek Library, Lewis & Clark College

entry.title: "Thomas Jefferson, President of the United States of America"
entry.summary:
19 x 31 cm.

Reprint limited to 250 copies of the form carried by Lewis and Clark to be presented to friendly Indian chiefs.
entry.content:
Title "Thomas Jefferson, President of the United States of America"

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

Description 19 x 31 cm.

Reprint limited to 250 copies of the form carried by Lewis and Clark to be presented to friendly Indian chiefs.

Publisher Yale University Press

Date 1964

Format PDF

Language English

Type Copy

entry.title: Poulson's American General Advertiser
entry.summary:
Volume LVI—No. 15,000
54 x 39 cm., four pages total

Second page, fifth column. "A Giant Tree" discusses a massive Poplar tree, which "stood near Lewis' ferry…Can anyone inform us of its equal?"

entry.title: New Hampshire Sentinel
entry.summary:
Vol. VIII—No. 412
47 x 28 cm., four pages total

Second page, middle of second column. "House of Representatives" contains a single sentence noting that a Congressional Bill would compensate Lewis and Clark for exploring the interior of Louisiana.

entry.title: Freeman's Friend
entry.summary:
Volume II—No. 17
49 x 29 cm., four pages total

Beginning at the bottom of the fourth column on the second page, and continuing on the next, this article notes the accomplishments of the expedition and says Lewis and Clark "deserve well of their country."
entry.content:

entry.title: The Repertory
entry.summary:
Vol. III—No. 99
50 x 33 cm., four pages total

First page, second paragraph from the bottom. This article notes the success of Lewis and Clark's expedition.
This article is the same as the one that appeared in The Witness on December 10, 1806.
entry.content:

Publisher The Repertory

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: The Witness
entry.summary:
Vol. II—No. 69
48 x 30 cm., four pages total

Third page, third column, fourth paragraph. This article notes the accomplishments of the expedition and describes it as a success.
This is the same article as the one in The Repertory on December 12, 1806.
entry.content:

entry.title: The National Aegis
entry.summary:
Vol. V—No. 250
47 x 30 cm., four pages total

Third page, top of first column. This single paragraph article announces that Lewis and Clark had arrived in St. Louis. It gives a brief description of the expedition and notes that their journals will be published.
entry.content:
Title The National Aegis

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

Description Vol. V—No. 250
47 x 30 cm., four pages total

Third page, top of first column. This single paragraph article announces that Lewis and Clark had arrived in St. Louis. It gives a brief description of the expedition and notes that their journals will be published.

Publisher The National Aegis

Date November 12, 1806

Format PDF

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: New Hampshire Sentinel
entry.summary:
Vol. VIII—No. 399
46 x 27 cm., four pages total

Third page, middle of the first column. "Domestic" is an extract of a letter from St. Louis dated September 23, 1806 that announces the arrival of Lewis and Clark in St. Louis.
entry.content:

entry.title: The Witness
entry.summary:
Vol. II—No. 64
48 x 30 cm., four pages total

Second page, third column. "Domestic News" announces that the Lewis and Clark expedition had returned from its journey and arrived in St. Louis. The article briefly describes the expedition and mentions Lewis's plans to return to Washington, D.C.
entry.content:

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

48 x 30 cm., four pages total

Second page, third column. "Domestic News" announces that the Lewis and Clark expedition had returned from its journey and arrived in St. Louis. The article briefly describes the expedition and mentions Lewis's plans to return to Washington, D.C.

Publisher The Witness

Date November 5, 1806

Format PDF

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: The Balance and Columbian Repository
entry.summary:
Vol. V—No. 44
31 x 24 cm., eight pages total

Sixth page, halfway down the second column. This article is a part of a letter written to Thomas Jefferson. The letter describes Lewis and Clark's winter at Fort Clatsop and the Columbia River Basin.
entry.content:

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: New Hampshire Sentinel
entry.summary:
Vol. VII—No. 365
46 x 28 cm., four pages total

First page, bottom of third column. "Ninth Congress: First Session" Letter from Thomas Jefferson describing the early part of the expedition.
This article is the same one that appears in both the Columbian Centinel on March 5, 1806 as well as The Repertory on March 7, 1806.
entry.content:

entry.title: The Repertory
entry.summary:
Volume III—No. 19
50 x 34 cm., four pages total

First page, fourth column. The "National Legislature" section contains a letter from Thomas Jefferson describing the progress of Lewis and Clark's expedition.
This article is the same as the one published in the New Hampshire Sentinel from March 15, 1806.
entry.content:
Title The Repertory

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

Description Volume III—No. 19
50 x 34 cm., four pages total

First page, fourth column. The "National Legislature" section contains a letter from Thomas Jefferson describing the progress of Lewis and Clark's expedition.
This article is the same as the one published in the New Hampshire Sentinel from March 15, 1806.

Publisher The Repertory

Date March 7, 1806

Format PDF

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: Columbian Centinel & Massachusetts Federalist
entry.summary:
No. 3, Vol. 45—Whole No. 2291
50 x 34 cm., four pages total

First page, fifth column, fifth paragraph. This letter from Thomas Jefferson describes the progression of Lewis and Clark's expedition including when it began. It also notes that a letter and some maps had been sent to the president from the Mandan villages on April 7, 1805. The content of this letter was presented to both houses of Congress.
This article is the same as the one published in the New Hampshire Sentinel from March 15, 1806.
entry.content:
Title Columbian Centinel & Massachusetts Federalist

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

Description No. 3, Vol. 45—Whole No. 2291
50 x 34 cm., four pages total

First page, fifth column, fifth paragraph. This letter from Thomas Jefferson describes the progression of Lewis and Clark's expedition including when it began. It also notes that a letter and some maps had been sent to the president from the Mandan villages on April 7, 1805. The content of this letter was presented to both houses of Congress.
This article is the same as the one published in the New Hampshire Sentinel from March 15, 1806.

Publisher Columbian Centinel & Massachusetts Federalist

Date March 5, 1806

Format PDF

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: The Independent Chronicle
entry.summary:
Volume XXXVII — No. 2471
50 x 30 cm., four pages total.

Second page, second column. "By The Mails" In a letter dated January 7th, it's noted that as of August 19th Capt. Lewis was 850 miles up the Missouri River, and was expected to winter with Mandan Indians about 1300 miles up the Missouri.
entry.content:
Title The Independent Chronicle

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

Description Volume XXXVII — No. 2471
50 x 30 cm., four pages total.

Second page, second column. "By The Mails" In a letter dated January 7th, it's noted that as of August 19th Capt. Lewis was 850 miles up the Missouri River, and was expected to winter with Mandan Indians about 1300 miles up the Missouri.

Publisher The Independent Chronicle

Date January 17, 1805

Format PDF

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: Columbian Centinel
entry.summary:
No. 41, Vol. 42
50 x 34 cm., four pages total.

Second page, middle of first column. This is a brief announcement that the expedition had made it 850 miles up the Missouri River with no problems, and that the expedition expected to winter with the Mandan Indians.
entry.content:
Title Columbian Centinel

Subject Lewis & Clark Expedition 19th Century Newspapers

Description No. 41, Vol. 42
50 x 34 cm., four pages total.

Second page, middle of first column. This is a brief announcement that the expedition had made it 850 miles up the Missouri River with no problems, and that the expedition expected to winter with the Mandan Indians.

Publisher Columbian Centinel

Date January 16, 1805

Format PDF

Language English

Type Newspaper

entry.title: The Independent Chronicle
entry.summary:
Volume XXXVI—No. 2406
53 x 32 cm., four pages total.

Second page, second column. "National Legislature" article details the proceedings from the second session of the Eighth Congress, during which the amelioration of the territorial government of Louisiana was discussed.
entry.content:
